Award.AwardTitle: "Deprivation" and "Enrichment" in Infant Spatial Cognitive Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The typical infant undergoes a psychological revolution between 7 and 9 months of age. There are so many changes involving numerous psychological functions, affecting domains so different from one another, and taking place within such a narrow time span that maturation has been postulated to account for the revolution. However, recent studies in the researcher's laboratory suggest a different interpretation. The onset of locomotor experience (such as crawling) is a potential determinant of many, if not most, of these changes. The proposed research will confirm or disconfirm the role of locomotor experience on a set of these changes. The proposed work has three goals. The first goal is to conduct a true experiment to examine the influence of locomotion. This study will randomly assign prelocomotor infants to conditions in which (a) such babies can control a powered-mobility device (PMD) to provide active locomotor experience, (b) babies receive passive locomotor experience in the PMD (no active control but otherwise have the same experience as those in the first group), and (c) a control group in which there is no locomotor experience, but rather fine motor training. The second goal is to test whether delays in locomotor experience linked to motor handicaps (in this case, infants with spina bifida) go along with delays in psychological development for the period of the delay in self-produced locomotion, followed by a spurt in functioning upon the delayed acquisition of locomotion. The third goal is to determine whether early crawlers, late crawlers, and normative-age crawlers differ or are the same in showing the psychological revolution mentioned before. Outcome assessments include tests for self-development (visual proprioception), memory for locations, joint visual attention, and concept formation.

This research draws its significance from theoretical and practical implications. In behavioral science, the importance of self-movement as a cause of psychological change dates back to the work of Berkeley in 1709 and has continued in studies by other prominent researchers through the centuries. Despite its lengthy historical tradition, the effect of motor activity on psychological function has been controversial, being refuted, ignored, or given second place to exposure to sensory stimulation. The proposed research should provide findings crucial to clarifying the controversy over the relative contributions of self-produced movement (versus sensory exposure). The project also has clinical implications. First, it investigates a major understudied developmental disability (spina bifida). In addition, the project can confirm whether motoric delays negatively impact spatial cognitive skills in infants and children with motor impairments. An especially important long-term implication of the proposed work will depend on the outcome of the studies using the powered-mobility device. If the device proves successful in bringing about psychological changes in otherwise prelocomotor infants, it can be used to intervene and to provide "artificial" locomotor experience with positive psychological outcomes for infants with locomotor handicaps.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Parents, pediatricians, and behavioral scientists have all noted that infants between 7 and 9 months of age undergo huge changes in psychological functioning. These changes involve emotion, spatial understanding, beginnings of language acquisition, control of posture and several other skills, some clear cut, some subtle. These changes are so widespread, so evident in the child’s behavior, and underlie the acquisition of so many future skills, that most observers attribute the changes to maturation (i.e. require no special experiences). However, research by us points to the role of experience locomoting as the trigger of the psychological changes. The present research was designed to confirm the earlier unexpected findings about locomotor experience.

How does one go about testing for the role of self-movement on mental development? The title of the grant application was “deprivation” and “enrichment” processes in infant development. Here is why we chose these words. We studied the role of deprivation of motoric experience by using an experiment of nature by studying infants with spina bifida. Such infants are delayed for four months or longer in acquiring crawling and allow us to ask the question: Is the psychological development of these infants delayed for the period of the delay in their acquisition of crawling, and then do they show a spurt in their psychological functioning following their delayed acquisition of crawling? If so, the role of motoric experience is supported. “Enrichment” refers to the provision of locomotor experience to babies who are not yet able to crawl on their own. The question with this approach involves asking whether the provision of artificial self-controlled locomotion to otherwise non crawling babies result in an improvement in psychological development. We provided “enrichment” by having infants randomly assigned to groups in which (A) the otherwise prelocomotor infant controls a powered go cart and provides him/her with movement experience; (B) comparing the performance of A babies with those having identical patterns of movement, but not controlled by themselves, controlled by the A babies; (C) Providing a third group with motor skill training that does not involve locomotion (fine motor skills, object manipulation, etc.) In brief, one thrust of this research involved accelerating the child’s development by providing experiences they otherwise would not have had until they began to locomote on their own.

Both approaches yielded positive findings indicating that locomotor experience was instrumental in bringing about psychological changes. What were these skills: the development of the wariness of heights, their acquisition of postural control, their ability to detect a constant form embedded within variable displays (concept formation), and the ability to follow the point and gaze of another person towards a distant target.

Without exception, all of the cognitive motor tasks on which the infants were tested showed that infants with locomotor experience demonstrated better mental performance than infants who were not yet crawling.

The study on the cognitive tests of the children with spina bifida confirmed strongly that these infants were delayed until they acquired locomotor skills. The study using the enrichment (go- cart) revealed that the prelocomotor infants who controlled the go-cart behaved like locomotor infants confirming our hypothesis. With minor exceptions, these findings were obtained with all
the psychological tests administered to the babies. The conclusion is clear: locomotor experience is a powerful organizer of psychological development.

Finally, a supplemental grant awarded by the National Science Foundation dealt with a discovery of a different type of linkage between locomotor experience and psychological development. It dealt with the linkage of walking onset and psychological changes. We have discovered that with walking onset, babies show a spurt in both understanding the meaning of words and producing words. This has been demonstrated in a study of the same infants as they developed walking between the ages of 11 and 14 months. The onset of walking always preceded the language spurts just described. This finding has been confirmed in four additional studies comparing infants of the same age who are walking or still crawling, rendering the discovery as a robust finding unexpected in the literature. Furthermore, studies showed that the search for hidden objects, the infant’s ability to follow the point and gaze gesture from another person, also proved to be better in the walking babies than the crawling babies of the same age. These findings have central relevance for psychological theory which typically ignores the importance of motor development for psychological functioning. That traditional view must be revised. Furthermore, pediatric thought must be revised as well. The skills we have studied must be considered related to motoric experiences opening up new avenues for treatment of children with orthopedic and perhaps neurological handicaps.
